key_points.point_content: More than two-thirds of start-ups never deliver a positive return to investors.
Commonly cited reason for failure is inadequacies of founders, but this oversimplifies the situation.
Six patterns of failure identified; focus on two most common avoidable reasons start-ups fail.
Start-ups can fail due to 'good idea, bad bedfellows' where founders lack industry experience and team or investors are not well suited.
Start-ups can fail due to 'false starts' where entrepreneurs skip customer discovery and launch products prematurely.
Entrepreneurs often have a bias for action and passion that can lead to premature product launch and skipping critical research.
A structured three-step product design process can help avoid false starts: problem definition, solution development, and solution validation.
Conventional wisdom advice like 'Just do it', 'Be persistent', 'Bring passion', 'Bootstrap', and 'Grow' can backfire and contribute to failure if followed blindly.
A major reason why companies fail, is that they run into the problem of their being little or no market for the product that they have built.
Entrepreneurs are too optimistic about how easy it will be to acquire customers, often leading to a business model failure.
The cost of acquiring a customer (CAC) must be less than the lifetime value of that customer (LTV) for a sustainable business model.
A weak management team is a common cause of startup failure, leading to poor strategy, execution, and team building.
Startups often fail because they run out of cash before reaching key milestones that increase valuation or enable further financing.
Failing to develop a product that meets the market need or achieve product/market fit causes startup failure.
The number one reason why start-ups fail was 'no market need.'
Nine of the top 20 reasons for startup failures were related to customers – not meeting customers’ needs, not listening to them or even ignoring them.
Startups fail when they are not solving a market problem, even if they have great technology and expertise.
Product design that didn’t meet customers’ needs can cause startup failure.
Not listening to customers and not getting feedback can lead to failure.
Seven of the top 20 reasons for failure were related to the people and/or culture of the company.
Not having the right people on board can cause failure.
Lack of alignment among founders and investors can lead to failure.
Lack of focus or passion can doom startups.
Only two of the top 20 reasons for failure were due to money, indicating that people and customer connection are more critical.
Failure often happens when people inside the company don’t care about customers or don’t cultivate a customer-centered culture.
Founders not interested in the domain can lead to products that don’t meet customers’ needs and failure.
Running out of cash or failing to raise new capital is the top reason startups fail.
No market need is the second most common reason for startup failure.
Startups often fail because they get outcompeted by others in the market.
A flawed business model can lead to startup failure.
Regulatory or legal challenges can cause startups to shut down.
Pricing and cost issues can make a startup unsustainable.
Having the wrong team or lack of key hires can contribute to failure.
Mistiming the product launch can lead to failure.
Poor product quality or not meeting user needs can cause failure.
Disharmony among team members or investors can be fatal.
A pivot gone bad can lead to startup failure.
Burnout or lack of passion among founders and team members can cause failure.
The biggest reasons why startups fail is they create a product that the market just doesn’t want.
Running out of money before you can get anywhere is a big issue for startups.
Your team can make-or-break your startup, as 23 percent of failed startups know all too well.
Getting outcompeted is the reason why 19 percent of startups fail.
Startups fail because they can’t balance pricing and cost issues.
Sometimes, startup Founders just come up short when it comes to product quality.
17 percent of startups failed because they lacked a business model.
Poor marketing is a major reason a lot of startups fail.
Ignoring customers and user feedback is a reason why startups fail.
Some startups launch before their time or too late, causing failure.
Lack of focus causes 13 percent of startups to fail.
Disharmony on team or with investors can lead to startup failure.
Pivoting can sometimes lead startups in the wrong direction and cause failure.
Six distinct patterns that account for the vast majority of startup failures.
Bad Bedfellows: The wrong team, investors, or partners can sink a venture just as quickly as the founder's talents and instincts can help it succeed.
False Starts: Following advice to 'fail fast' and 'launch before you’re ready' can lead to wasting time and capital on the wrong solutions.
False Promises: Success with early adopters can be misleading and give founders unwarranted confidence to expand.
Speed Traps: Hypergrowth can spell disaster for even the most promising ventures despite pressure to 'get big fast'.
Help Wanted: Rapidly scaling startups need lots of capital and talent, but mistakes can leave them suddenly in short supply of both.
Cascading Miracles: The bigger the vision, the more things that can go wrong.
Reasons for failure include money running out, being in the wrong market, a lack of research, bad partnerships, ineffective marketing, and not being an expert in the industry.
Money ran out because it stopped coming in due to poorly managed costs or insufficient sales, or inability to obtain financing.
Targeting too broad a market or everyone in a town leads to failure; a narrowly defined niche is easier to market to the right audience.
Lack of research leads to offering products or services that customers do not want.
Bad partnerships cause internal conflict and can dissolve the business without clear resolution and defined duties.
Bad marketing can cause failure; hiring marketing expertise can bring in more revenue than the cost.
Not being an expert or lacking business skills leads to struggle and failure.
Running out of money is the leading cause of startup failure.
Lack of financing or investor interest is a major reason for startup failure.
No business plan or model is a common cause of startup failure.
Strong business planning with an eye towards profitability is the surest way to avoid failure.
Nearly 30% of founders recommend doing more research prior to launch to prevent failure.
About 70% of entrepreneurs will face potential business failure, often within 25 months of launching.
A lack of market need and mistimed products have become more prevalent reasons for failure, especially in 2020 due to COVID-19.
Pivoting can help startups avoid failure, with 75% of founders who pivoted reporting success.
The most common pivot strategy is updating or improving the business plan.
Advice from founders to prevent failure includes learning from mistakes, listening to customers, and ensuring market demand.
Most startups fail because they didn’t solve a problem that customers want to be solved.
42 percent of startups fail when they realize there is no market for their product or service.
Startups fail because the founders don’t pay attention to understanding customers' real needs and creating solutions for them.
Startups fail due to business model failure, including not understanding the market and positioning the business accordingly.
A poor management team is a major reason why startups fail, including lack of good leadership and passion.
Running out of cash is the number one reason startups fail.
Failing to address customers' real problems with the product leads to startup failure.
Most start-ups don’t succeed: More than two-thirds of them never deliver a positive return to investors.
Commonly cited reasons for failure focus on founders' inadequacies, but this oversimplifies the situation.
Six patterns of failure explain why many start-ups fail; two common avoidable reasons are discussed in detail.
Start-ups can fail due to 'Good Idea, Bad Bedfellows' where lack of industry experience and poor team or investor fit cause failure.
Start-ups can fail due to 'False Starts' where entrepreneurs skip upfront customer research and launch products prematurely.
Entrepreneurs should follow a structured product design process: problem definition, solution development, and solution validation.
Common entrepreneurial traits like bias for action, persistence, passion, frugality, and desire for growth can backfire and contribute to failure.
90% of startups in India fail within 5 years of inception.
Startups in India often imitate western ideas, which contributes to failure.
Lack of confidence in founders leads to startup failure.
Business models lacking innovation cause startups to fail.
Market saturation in India makes it difficult for startups to succeed.
Negative cash flow and working capital issues lead to startup failure.
Forceful expansion before adequate profit margin causes losses.
Lack of a motivated team contributes to startup failure.
Not taking customer feedback seriously leads to losing customers.
Lack of innovation is a major reason why startups fail, with 77% of venture capitalists thinking Indian startups lack innovation or unique business models.
Lack of funds and a profitable business model leads to startup failure.
Lack of focus on a single core service or product can cause startups to fail.
Failure to achieve product-market fit, meaning the product does not meet consumer needs, causes startups to fail.
Leadership gaps and lack of strong vision contribute to startup failure.
Lack of agility and adaptability to change can cause startups to fail.
Failure of the business model, including inability to acquire and monetize customers, leads to startup failure.
Lack of talent and competency is a significant reason for startup failure.
Ignoring customers and not addressing their feedback can cause startups to fail.
The government and bureaucratic inefficiency are major reasons for startup failures in India.
Most startups fail due to a combination of factors, not just money troubles.
The copycat approach, replicating successful ventures without innovation, leads to failure.
Poor financial management and money troubles cause startups to fail.
Ease of doing business in India is low due to red-tapism, bad infrastructure, and corruption, contributing to startup failures.
Market not ready for innovation can cause startups to fail.
Lack of ownership among founders can lead to startup failure.
Unplanned approach and lack of business planning cause startups to fail.
Bad customer service leads to startup failure.
Staff dissatisfaction and partner troubles contribute to startup failure.
Comfort zone issues and failure to adapt to market changes cause startups to fail.
Poor marketing can cause even good products to fail.
The primary reason many new businesses fail early on is no market need for the product or service.
Startups fail because their founders often lack a sense of self awareness.
Most startups fail in the first or second year due to wrong market or industry selection.
Many startups fail due to the lack of vision or wrong vision for the company’s product.
If the business model of the startups fails then you cannot exist or compete in the market.
Many Startups fail because of the weak feedback system of the company.
Many startups fail in the initial years of operation due to poor management team.
Starting a business without proper research about the market can prove to be final nail in the coffin of your dream of starting business.
Many startups fail due to the location of business, including physical and internet location.
Many startups fail in the initial years because the founders are not aware about the cash burn rate of the company.
If the startups companies fail to develop the product as per the market need then they cannot sustain or succeed in the market.
